channel.title: Morning Money
channel.description: Delivered daily by 8 a.m., Morning Money examines the latest news in finance, politics and policy — and on Fridays, Morning Money: Capital Risk highlights the downstream effects on markets.

item.title: For the Fed, old economic data beats no economic data
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: The banks' delicate dance
item.description: JPMorgan and other big Wall Street institutions are navigating opposing forces in Trump’s Washington.
item.dc:creator: By Aiden Reiter

item.title: Summers slips into fall
item.description: The Larry Summers era is over.
item.dc:creator: By Victoria Guida, Sam Sutton and Michael Stratford
item.dc:contributor: By Victoria Guida, Sam Sutton and Michael Stratford

item.title: The Windy City’s Treasury market #resistance
item.description: Rank-and-file Democratic voters are increasingly rewarding state and local leaders who break from conventional wisdom on policy and politicking.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: Treasury’s crypto headache
item.description: A high-stakes lobbying war between banks and cryptocurrency companies is becoming a new headache for the Trump administration.
item.dc:creator: By Jasper Goodman

item.title: America’s $6 billion ‘seed fund’ has gone dark
item.description: The longest government shutdown in U.S. history may be nearing an end, but for a lapsed $6 billion small business innovation lifeline, there is still no solution in sight.
item.dc:creator: By Katherine Hapgood

item.title: Trump’s got a paycheck problem
item.description: The drubbing Republicans took at the ballot box last week highlighted President Donald Trump’s weakness on the issue of affordability.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: Tick tock: The clock gets louder for Atkins’ SEC
item.description: Securities and Exchange Commission Chair Paul Atkins has big plans for his agency, but less and less time to get them done.
item.dc:creator: By Declan Harty

item.title: ‘It’s a yellow brick road for tech companies’
item.description: Astronomical investment in artificial intelligence is only accelerating. But that spending is increasingly coming from borrowing, rather than cash.
item.dc:creator: By Yasmin Khorram

item.title: Mamdani wins. Wall Street survives.
item.description: The capital of global finance will wake up this morning to the reality that a self-avowed democratic socialist is about to become its next mayor.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton, Aiden Reiter and Declan Harty
item.dc:contributor: By Sam Sutton, Aiden Reiter and Declan Harty

item.title: CFPB’s breaking point
item.description: Months of turmoil at the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau are set to reach a breaking point in the coming weeks.
item.dc:creator: By Michael Stratford

item.title: How Yellen's shadow still looms over Treasury
item.description: With deficits growing in the U.S., and little appetite from either political party to dial things back, long-dated Treasury yields will see less relief from Fed cuts than short-term rates.
item.dc:creator: By Aiden Reiter and Victoria Guida
item.dc:contributor: By Aiden Reiter and Victoria Guida

item.title: Saudi Arabia’s big pivot to Wall Street
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s economy has undergone a significant transformation since Crown Prince Mohammed Bin Salman took power.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton and Michael Stratford
item.dc:contributor: By Sam Sutton and Michael Stratford

item.title: Bill Ackman on Trump’s hands-on capitalism
item.description: The U.S. government is $38 trillion in the hole. Bill Ackman isn’t sweating it.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton and Victoria Guida
item.dc:contributor: By Sam Sutton and Victoria Guida

item.title: Crypto’s second wind in the Senate
item.description: Less than a week after cryptocurrency industry executives flocked to Capitol Hill in a bid to rescue a landmark legislative overhaul of digital asset regulations, signs of life for the effort are emerging in the Senate.
item.dc:creator: By Jasper Goodman

item.title: Trump's Gaza gamble: Putting a price on peace
item.description: Gaza’s economy is in ruins.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton and Declan Harty
item.dc:contributor: By Sam Sutton and Declan Harty

item.title: Trump's two-speed economy
item.description: Weaknesses in the real economy have been masked by hundreds of billions of dollars in artificial intelligence investments.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: About Europe’s $600 billion investment pledge…
item.description: A cornerstone of President Donald Trump’s trade deal with the European Commission was a pledge to invest $600 billion in U.S. projects. Leaders in the bloc have already questioned whether it’s enforceable.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: A startup takes on Trump’s Wall Street regulator
item.description: The lawsuit marks a rare display of corporate resistance in Trump 2.0.
item.dc:creator: By Declan Harty and Yasmin Khorram
item.dc:contributor: By Declan Harty and Yasmin Khorram

item.title: What the regional bank sell-off says about the economy
item.description: The sell-off in bank stocks that rattled markets last week is a sign that the economy is beginning to strain.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: The haves and have-nots in the AI economy
item.description: AI’s rising tide isn’t lifting all boats.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: Crypto’s new Capitol Hill headache
item.description: The centerpiece of Republicans’ cryptocurrency policy agenda is stuck in the mud in the U.S. Senate, and it is becoming increasingly clear that it has little chance of becoming law this year.
item.dc:creator: By Jasper Goodman

item.title: Trump bets on Argentina as IMF-World Bank gather
item.description: Global economic policymakers are gathering for the annual meetings of the International Monetary Fund and World Bank to take up a host of global financial challenges.
item.dc:creator: By Michael Stratford

item.title: The Labor Department’s data woes are about to get worse
item.description: The longer Congress is stuck in a stalemate over government funding, the greater the chance that furloughed Labor Department employees won’t have the data to provide accurate updates on where the economy stands.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton and Nick Niedzwiadek
item.dc:contributor: By Sam Sutton and Nick Niedzwiadek

item.title: What the threat to federal workers’ backpay means for the economy
item.description: The federal government is the largest employer in the country. When it fails to make payroll, that pulls down spending and creates a drag on economic growth.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: ‘Zero guardrails’: CEOs brace for Trump scrutiny
item.description: In a report out this morning, GSR’s risk advisory council identified public criticism from Trump as the leading reputational risk now faced by companies and global organizations.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: ‘A gut punch’: Government shutdown jams up the revived IPO market
item.description: The IPO slowdown is one of the most concrete examples yet of how the government shutdown is hitting investors.
item.dc:creator: By Declan Harty

item.title: Trump’s economy is strong. Just not for first-time Trump voters.
item.description: President Donald Trump’s economy is growing steadily and the recession fears that characterized his early days in office have mostly faded.
item.dc:creator: By Sam Sutton

item.title: Billions in AI investments are caught in regulatory crosshairs
item.description: The fight between California and Washington over who should regulate artificial intelligence is heating up. Startups are caught in the crosshairs.
item.dc:creator: By Yasmin Khorram and Victoria Guida
item.dc:contributor: By Yasmin Khorram and Victoria Guida

item.title: Why a shutdown looms over the housing market
item.description: Congress is on the brink of creating a new housing market disruption, as lawmakers careen toward a government funding train wreck that appears likely to cause a shutdown.
item.dc:creator: By Jasper Goodman
